Line 8: Line 8:
Virtually no research has been conducted regarding the prevalance of necrophilic attraction among humans. Klaf and Brown (1958) commented that, "although necrophilia is rarely described, such fantasies are more common than is generally supposed."<ref>Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652.</ref>
Virtually no research has been conducted regarding the prevalance of necrophilic attraction among humans. Klaf and Brown (1958) commented that, "although necrophilia is rarely described, such fantasies are more common than is generally supposed."<ref>Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652.</ref>
â
Rosman and Resnick (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia:<ref>Rosman, Jonathan P., and Resnick, Phillip J. (1989). "Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia," ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law'', 17, 153-163.</ref>
+
Rosman and Resnick (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):<ref>Rosman, Jonathan P., and Resnick, Phillip J. (1989). "Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia," ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law'', 17, 153-163.</ref>
â
<blockquote>(1) The necrophile develops poor self-esteem, perhaps due in part to a significant loss; (a) He (usually male) is very fearful of rejection by women and he desires a sexual object who is incapable of rejecting him; and/or (b) He is fearful of the dead, and transforms his fear of the deadâby means of reaction formationâinto a desire for the dead.<br /> (2) He develops an exciting fantasy of sex with a corpse, sometimes after exposure to a corpse.</blockquote>
+
#The necrophile develops poor self-esteem, perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
  +
#:(a) He (usually male) is very fearful of rejection by women and he desires a sexual object who is incapable of rejecting him; and/or
  +
#:(b) He is fearful of the dead, and transforms his fear of the deadâby means of reaction formationâinto a desire for the dead.
  +
#(2) He develops an exciting fantasy of sex with a corpse, sometimes after exposure to a corpse.</blockquote>
  +
The authors also reported that, of their sample of 'necrophiliacs,' 68% were motivated by a desire for an unresisting and unrejecting partner; 21% by a want for reunion with a lost partner; 15% by sexual attraction to corpses; 15% by a desire for comfort or to overcome feelings of isolation; and 12% by a desire to remedy low self-esteem by expressing power over a corpse (pp. 159). (It could be surmised that only the 15% motivated by an attraction to corpses were true necrophiliacs.)
===Consensuality issue===
===Consensuality issue===
Line 34: Line 34:
==Legal status==
==Legal status==
===Legality in the United States===
===Legality in the United States===
  +
As of May, 2006, there is no federal legislation specifically barring sex with a corpse.[http://www.burknet.com/robsfantasy/section3a.html] Multiple states have their own laws:
  +
*Alabama - Class C felony under [http://www.legislature.state.al.us/CodeofAlabama/1975/13A-11-13.htm 13A-11-13]
*Alabama - Class C felony under [http://www.legislature.state.al.us/CodeofAlabama/1975/13A-11-13.htm 13A-11-13]
*Alaska - Class A misdemeanour under [http://touchngo.com/lglcntr/akstats/Statutes/Title11/Chapter61/Section130.htm 11-61-130]
*Alaska - Class A misdemeanour under [http://touchngo.com/lglcntr/akstats/Statutes/Title11/Chapter61/Section130.htm 11-61-130]
